import React from "react"; import "./styles.css"; const CipherInfo = () => { return (
< div class="main-heading">

üîê Caesar Cipher

A Classical Encryption Technique

üìå Overview

The Caesar Cipher is one of the oldest encryption methods. It works by shifting letters forward by a fixed number of positions in the alphabet.

üîÑ How It Works

  • Choose a shift key (K): Determines how many places each letter moves.
  • Encrypt: Each letter shifts forward by K positions.
  • Decrypt: Shift is reversed to retrieve the original text.

Example (Shift Key = 3)

PlaintextHELLO
CiphertextKHOOR

üí° Strengths & Weaknesses

‚úî Advantages

  • Simple & Fast ‚Äì Easy to implement with minimal computation.
  • No Key Exchange Required ‚Äì Only a shift value is needed.
  • Useful for Learning ‚Äì A great introduction to cryptographic concepts.
  • Historical Significance ‚Äì One of the earliest encryption techniques.

‚ùå Disadvantages

  • Easily Breakable ‚Äì Can be cracked using brute force (only 25 possible shifts).
  • No Key Variation ‚Äì A fixed shift makes it predictable.
  • Does Not Hide Letter Frequency ‚Äì Preserves patterns, making frequency analysis trivial.
  • Not Used in Modern Cryptography ‚Äì Not secure against modern cryptanalysis.

üõ† Python Code

          
{`def caesar_cipher(text, key, mode='encrypt'):
    alphabets = 'abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz'
    result = ''

    for letter in text.lower():
        if letter in alphabets:
            index = alphabets.find(letter)
            new_index = (index + key) % 26 if mode == 'encrypt' else (index - key) % 26
            result += alphabets[new_index]
        else:
            result += letter
    return result

# Encrypt
print(caesar_cipher("Hello World", 3))  

# Decrypt
print(caesar_cipher("Khoor Zruog", 3, mode='decrypt'))`}
); }; export default CipherInfo;
